narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the basic ideas in astronomy, including Einstein's Theory of General Relativity, black holes, dark energy, and dark matter.
I learned about many interesting topics in the area of physics including: general relativity, time, black holes, origins of the universe, exoplanets, inflation, and many other interesting topics.
I learned a great deal about various concepts in astrophysics, and I gained exposure to reading scientific journal papers.

I learned a great deal about the nature of our universe, as well as current and past research projects to uncover more. I questioned my own thoughts and experiences with how I perceived the universe, managing to compare and contrast them heavily with what science is leading us towards. I also learned many helpful tidbits about the scientific community, the methods used to do research, and how to write an effective scientific paper.
I learned important and relevant concepts in astrophysics, including general relativity, dark energy, and black holes.

In this course, we learned about a variety of astrophysics topics, and I thought that it was a good base of information to give us some insight into any astrophysics we encounter in the future. The midterm and final project were a great way to practice synthesizing information and presenting scientific research.

Basic knowledge of astrophysics, which went into detail about the overarching concepts in the field. Understanding of the overall scientific community and its procedures. Engagement with topics that are not only applicable to astrophysics-- Professor Urry made sure to remind us that science goes beyond what we are usually taught.
I developed a better ability to glean knowledge from difficult papers, which is a very helpful skill that I will take from this class.
I learned about the basics of general relativity and special relativity, concept of time and space, as well as how to read and find academic research papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Meg Urry is a wonderful teacher and she really helps you understand the complex ideas. The biggest weakness of the course is the 10 page single spaced final paper.
I think the guest speakers provided extremely interesting information, and the assigned readings were also very informative.

This course was strong beyond my expectations. I will get my one suggestion out of the way first, just so I can gush about everything else later. As a student who is admittedly not great in physics, I wish we had a bit more thorough of an explanation into some of the more confusing formulas and processes, but since the class was more about understanding, discussion, and inquiry than implementation, this wasn't a huge deal. Everything else about this class was fantastic. Professor Urry did an amazing job introducing and teaching topics that admittedly made my head spin but that grew on me over time. She always had excellent visual representations and analogies to help us understand, and these were greatly appreciated. This engaging style of teaching really helped the confusing subject matter of the class stick.

Some strengths include the discussion-oriented nature of the class, the interesting assigned readings and papers, as well as the guest lectures. One way this course could be improved is by providing clearer feedback on weekly write-ups and midterm presentations.

I think the structure of the course and the topics it covered were very effective for giving us background in many areas of astrophysics. It also prepared us well for becoming astrophysics researchers through the in-class presentations we did.

Professor Urry is the biggest strength of this course. She is candid, engaging, and extremely knowledgeable. She is a world renowned astrophysicists and it shows! While most of the time was spent discussing the material, we also touched on topics beyond science -- like the involvement of women and voices of color in the community. Overall, I could not recommend this class and her more. Only weakness is that at times it can take her a while to grade material, which could leave you clueless as to how you are doing in the class.

I think this class was good because I felt we as a class learned together, but my only difficulty was that with the challenging material I was unsure how much I should actually be expected to understand, and I had some trouble verbalizing the questions that I had.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My favorite part was guest speakers because it was a nice change from the daily Zoom routine. More breakout rooms would also facilitate more discussion.
The discussions on Zoom actually went pretty smoothly, and there was never a lack of discussion. I think the method of calling on people who hadn't previously spoken was effective.

This class honestly didn't feel like a virtual class. I feel like this was because I was so engaged. Every lecture, discussion, and meeting felt like it was happening right in front of me. My only qualm was that we didn't get to do some admittedly exciting things, like the art gallery tour and discussions with professionals, in person, but for the circumstances, the way we did get to witness them were amazing.
The virtual zoom session was engaging for the most part, and the small size of the class contributed to the breadth and level of class discussion.

I thought that the projects and presentations worked well in a virtual format, and I also thought that the reflections due each week were good ways for us to think about what we had learned. I like that we had partners for the projects because it allowed us to connect with others in the class in a way that is difficult in the virtual format.
I think the discussion worked as well as it possibly could have during this term, and I liked how the virtual discussion was handled as an ongoing trial and error so we could all give input.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this class to any student regardless of their major. It is great for a foundation in astronomy.
Yes; this course provides great insights on technological and scientific advances of the 20th and 21st centuries and does a great job explaining different principles of physics.
I would recommend this course because I learned a lot about astrophysics, and the topics discussed in class, such as the concept of time, were also very interesting.

I would recommend this class to anyone looking for an amazing science course. I am no physics person, but I felt myself engrossed and interested in the material nevertheless, and I believe I truly learned a lot of things that I'd typically never get the chance to think about.

Yes, this course is a great way to explore concepts in astronomy and astrophysics, without going into the complicated mathematics that these subjects entail. The weekly essays and occasional quizzes were beneficial in reinforcing knowledge throughout the semester.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student who wants to pursue astrophysics research in the future - I think it provides great background and presentation skills. I'd also recommend to anyone - the topics were interesting and class discussions were great.
Yes!! Please take it even if you are not interested in astrophysics. The class goes well beyond that. Or just take it to engage with Professor Urry!
I would recommend this class to another student who is interested in astronomy. The material was challenging but I feel like the format was made for students to succeed in the end.
